In 2014, author Natan Dubovitsky published
a short story entitled “Without Sky”,

in which he described the concept of “non-linear
war” through the lens of a fictional, futuristic
conflict.

Here, war was no longer a fight between two
easily-defined sides but instead multiple

factions with varied goals and constantly
changing allegiances colliding with each other;

where merely emerging victorious was a goal
of the “simple-hearted commanders of the

past” and instead defeat could be just as
useful a means of controlling a population
looking for answers in the resulting chaos.

It’s important to note that Dubovitsky is
in fact the pen name of Vladimir Putin’s
political advisor, Vladimir Surkov.

A man with a background in avant-garde art
and, as documentarian Adam Curtis describes,

whose aim it is to turn Russian politics into
a “bewildering, constantly changing piece

of theatre” in which the state would directly
sponsor opposing political groups in very

public ways; all as a means of keeping dissident
voices confused and unable to provide a coherent

narrative with which to effectively oppose
the establishment—essentially, you can’t
fight what you can’t accurately define.

No one can predict Putin’s movements as
directed by Surkov, and so his power has broadly
remained unchallenged.

The world, as it turns out, is a pretty terrifying
place where the idea of not making sense is
a powerful political tool.

It’s also what you might be thinking as
you hit new game on MGS4 and after some odd

TV shows and adverts for private military
contractors are transported directly to a

battlefield with multiple factions battling
it out and seemingly no reason as to why you’re
actually there.

It seems like there should be some kind of
briefing in between, but as long as you pick

new game, that briefing might as well not
exist.

Wait a minute, this was supposed to be the
big conclusion to wrap up everything from
Metal Gear’s past!
What’s the deal, Kojima?
This doesn’t make any sense.

But, playing it now, I feel like it might
be better this way—that it’s better, or

at least more true to life, that things don’t
make sense here.

See, I’ve always appreciated this game in
a lot of ways but I get that it’s flawed—that

its dialogue is inelegant, the length of its
cutscenes is ridiculous and that its narrative
reveals are daft.

But there’s something about booting up MGS4
in 2019 that gives it a new sense of meaning,

going beyond ironic enjoyment of its big dumb
action and incredibly bloated melodrama.

Rather, in the same way MGS2 has been revisited
as some kind of prophecy as to the progression

of internet culture, for example, there’s
something about the ways MGS4 diverts from

series formula coupled with the sheer absurdity
of its campier moments that all help to cement

Snake as a character truly out of time, that
have us sharing in his struggle to find narrative

resolution in an increasingly nonsensical
world and, as a result, end up reflecting

some of the anxieties that almost inevitably
come with living in the modern age.

And it all starts with that first cutscene,
where we begin to see things changing in subtle,

uncanny ways—the slow, measured infiltration
sequence in which Snake enters a facility

solo while getting the mission deets in hushed
terms, is replaced with a truck barrelling

into a town centre as Snake solemnly reflects
on how things aren’t the same anymore.

We’re long past the age of good guys vs
bad.

Previously it was him vs the world—the lone
action hero vs the people in the way whose

singular goal was to eliminate said action
hero.

Now, you enter a battle with some soldiers
against… some other soldiers and some robots

and no faction is really bothered about your
presence.
Is it a stealth game?

Does stealth really play into things when
you can freely run around?
Who are you really hiding from here?
Who are you fighting for?
Who is anyone fighting for here?
Does anyone care about your previous heroism?
Clearly not.

The masterful conclusion of Sons of Liberty,
the point at which its world falls apart—as

Raiden turns to Jack the Ripper; as the famously
stealth-oriented franchise morphs into what

fellow YouTuber Super Bunnyhop described as
a total bloodbath, shaking our understanding

of that world to its very core—is precisely
the starting point of Guns of the Patriots.
We start at pure chaos.

Snake has to deal with the fact that everything
is rejigged here.

Hell, things as simple as items are real-world
objects now; a far cry from the big spinning

boxes floating in the air found in previous
instalments.

They’re non-descript; strewn about the landscape
in a way that makes them indistinguishable

from rubbish; and Snake can’t readily identify
any of it until he puts on the equivalent
of his reading glasses.

The world can’t be so easily broken down
into discernible blocks now.

Snake’s self-worth is mechanically attached
to a military framework he can’t so readily

engage with anymore—that has moved past
him and his prior achievements.

In this new chaotic world (in a moment that,
when I first played it, had me internally

cheering at the return of the legend) he can
disguise himself as, well, his former self

and walk right out in front of people; because
as much as we know him as a truly iconic action

hero, in the grand scheme of things heroism
doesn’t mean anything here.

What we’ve come to know about the world
of Metal Gear Solid is butting up against

the fact that, well, the world we find Snake
in really is different now and starting from

the TV segments, the game honestly does a
pretty good job at illustrating how ingrained

into modern culture the militaristic mindset
has become—with an advert for a private

military somehow feeling less uncomfortable
than David Hayter being asked about a tattoo
behind his ear.

What struck me as I played through recently,
however, was just how well this sentiment
was conveyed throughout the rest of the game.

The glimpses we get of normalcy in this world—friendship,
family and home life, love—all occur within
a military context.

It’s what makes these scenes as goofy as
they are—most moments of melodrama in previous

games occurred outside of battle but here,
the world has been engulfed by war; as the
game states, it’s routine.

There’s no other opportunity for these scenes
to play themselves out, as nonsensical as
they are.

Even when Snake saves the day and Jonny gets
the girl in perhaps the daftest circumstances

ever, the wedding takes place on a military
airstrip because, well, where else is it going
to happen?

The theatrics of it all are beyond ridiculous
in their portrayal of such a relatively saccharine

ending, but it’s because of this weirdness
that it ends up saying a lot about the world

these characters are currently inhabiting
and the potential futility of their actions.

The war economy that turned conflict into
routine may be dead, but it isn’t some new

world order they’ve built by winning here,
the quote-unquote “heroes” have done what

they’ve always done in some capacity—uphold
the status quo and keep the plebs from being
affected too much.

The old relics still stand though—relics
that apparently bear a striking resemblance

to the shadowy organisation our protagonists
have just taken down.

Snake has managed to halt forward progress
momentarily, but that’s not to say the same

conflicts won’t start right back up again
in a matter of time.

And the interesting thing to me about all
of this is how, as much as the Metal Gear

games have helped define the way games tell
their stories, they’re also arguably games

about storytelling; about being able to find
and convey a coherent narrative in all of
this morally grey noise.

The Boss had to die as a scapegoat at the
end of 3, regardless of the truth, because

it was a more convenient story for the higher
ups and the alternative was nuclear war.
It was chaos.

Defining his own legacy is the only way Raiden
can deal with the existential teardown he’s
just experienced at the end of 2.

It’s what Snake told him to do; it’s the
hero of the story appearing at the end to

tell you that everything’s going to be OK
if you find your own way… and, well, we
see how that turns out.

See, MGS4 to me is the most direct the series
has been in confronting the notion that finding

such a convenient answer might not always
be possible (or that even if one is found,

that the world doesn’t simply stop at the
end of a story)—that the chaos our protagonists

have always fought against in some way might
end up winning out in the end and, as Surkov

detailed in “non-linear warfare”, things
just might not ever make sense… and that’s
terrifying.

The realisations and mysteries solved along
the way read as absurd and shmaltzy because
of course they do.

The idea that Para-medic is a founding member
of the Patriots ends up feeling as quaint

as Naomi and Otacon suddenly getting the hots
for each other or Sunny being bad at cooking
eggs.

It’s all on the same level; all ultimately
bears the same level of meaning and impact.

If you want a neat little bow put on everything,
of course it’s going to ring dissonantly—the
world doesn’t work like that.

And when you break all of that down, these
are pretty dark themes the game is tackling—confronting

us with the idea that our actions don’t
matter in the way we thought they once did;

that the world is moving to a place where
meaning becomes harder and harder to distinguish,

which in turn leaves us feeling more and more
powerless to make positive change within it.

You can’t fight that which you can’t accurately
define.

And playing MGS4 in 2019, free from the hype
that the game would resolve all the questions

I thought I wanted answered from previous
titles, I found myself less disappointed with

the reveals of the Patriots or the Meryl and
Jonny situation or the ridiculous amounts

of sensational theatrics on show, and found
that, combined with the game’s deconstruction

of heroism and legend, it all instead contributed
to a greater sense of unease that harkened

back to the original TV segments; all of which
had me asking myself “is this a world I
really want to preserve?

Or was Ocelot right to want to burn it to
the ground?”

Of course I’m not saying that this is somehow
the *right* way to read MGS4 or even that

it was intentional—over the years I’ve
come to view the idea of some singular auteur

guiding the entirety of a title’s vision
as a little hard to believe.

It’s beyond flawed, for sure; I can’t
disagree with almost any criticism brought
up against the game.

I’m just saying that, taken within a modern
context (in the same way we continue to revisit

and re-evaluate other Metal Gear games), MGS4
might not be the unwanted break from series

tradition that so many have brushed it off
as and might, in fact, have some interesting

insights to offer on the nature of political
control in the modern age.
